This is a board game which comes with Philip Pullman's book "Once Upon a Time in the North", the fifth book in the His Dark Materials series.
The board game is kept in a tuck pocket inside the back cover. It includes a board with printed instructions on the reverse, and a card which contains a Wind Compass and 6 player Balloon tokens.

It is a simple Roll-and-Move Children's game depicting competing aeronaughts seeking to survive the longest in the North Pole; the winner is decided by the last player not destroyed in the Polar Maelstrom. The game requires a Die which is not included. The Wind Compass is used to decide which direction the player's Balloon moves to when it lands on an appropriate space.

The game is a presented in an antique style in keeping with the general design of the period depicted in the books.

name: Börja räkna
description:
Börja räkna is a childrens game for Ages 5 and up.

This is an adventure game that is fun and educational.
Each child has their own play sheet and choses one task. Shuffle the tiles and then pick them one at a time. The child who has best managed to do their task is the winner.

Contents:
77 tiles
8 play sheets
Rules

name: Bamses skola: Former
description:
This is a childrens game for Ages 5 and up.

Fun and Educational.

You start with 6 pieces each and your job is to put together a triangle with a triangle and so on until you don't have any left. First player without any pieces left wins the game.

name: Across Ticklers
description:
Word game where players compete to create acrostic sentences, like this for "games":

Good
Acrostics
Make
Everyone
Smile

"Your friends and family will tickle you with the crazy acrostics they make. You'll even be tickled with the sentences you create."

name: Torchwood TCG
description:
From the website:

Captain Jack Harkness is a former Time Agent from the 51st Century. He has traveled in the Tardis in Doctor Who and now heads a team of experts on present-day Earth as they battle with aliens from other worlds, monsters from different dimensions, creatures from the dawn of time and rifts in the very fabric of the universe!

Together, Jack, Gwen Cooper, Toshiko Sato, Ianto Jones and Dr Owen Harper make up Torchwood, defenders of the Earth from alien invasion and a rift in time and space that tears right through Cardiff!

The Torchwood Trading Card Collection features 200 brand-new spectacular cards from both series of the TV show. Prepare to do battle with deadly alien sleeper assassins bent on destroying the world, alien entities that feed on memories, monstrous parasites that incubate inside human bodies and a demon that could cause the end of life on Earth.

The new Torchwood Trading Card Collection features special holo and lenticular super-rares and ultra-rares, plus a selection of power-boosting bonus cards that add exciting levels to players’ games.

Trading cards stats

200 unique designs based on both series one and series two of Torchwood
Pack odds: 160 common cards (8 in every pack); 25 rare (1 in every pack)
10 super-rare (1 in every 6 packs); 5 ultra-rare (1 in every 24 packs).
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Destination Sheffield
description:
A game of taxi driving through Sheffield. It's a rather random process of collecting fares, avoiding fines, and other such mishaps, while visiting many of Sheffield's tourist destinations.

One of many in the "Destination" series.

name: Pelle Svanslös: Klättra och kana
description:
In this childrens game the idea is for the cats to be the first to reach the cream. The game is a straight snakes-and-ladders clone with slides replacing the snakes. This means roll and move, ladders bring you forward, slides bring you backwards.

Contents:
1 board game
6 playing pieces (cats from the comic)
1 wheel of movement
rules (printed in lid)

The game was issued in a time when the "Pelle Svanslös" comic was very popular in Sweden, the only national comic of the time that could challenge Disney. Most images in the game are signed Carl-Börje (real name Börje Nilsson, cartoonist and comic magazine editor), the cartoonist who drew the comic, and the whole game could probably be credited to him (given that there is no original gameplay).

The six playing pieces are pictures of main characters from the comic, Pelle Svanslös (the hero without tail), Maja Gräddnos (his girlfriend), Feta Trisse (fat and smart cat), Elaka Måns (mean main enemy of Pelle), Frida (the scatter-brained one) and one of the twins Bill and Bull (the funny and dumb duo, sort of like Dupont and Dupond). A few more characters show on the gameboard and on the cover: Tusse Batong (policeman), Gullan från Arkadien (another good-looking girl-cat) and Murre från Skogstibble (farm cat). There are also some anonymous extra cats on the game board. All pictures follow the comic style perfectly, certainly a main feature of the game at the time.

name: Alphabet Pirates
description: Move your piece around the board and collect letter tiles. Making words from your tiles gains you "ducats" ... the first player to 25 ducats WINS! (woo-hoo!)
categories: Card Game, Nautical, Pirates, Word Game

name: Chinesenspiel
description: Chinesenspiel (meaning "Chinese game") is a 19th century German game of the Pachisi family, but simplified so there is only one piece per player. The board layout is similar to the Korean game Yut Nori.

name: 40K Skirmish
description: A game based on the Warhammer 40K universe. It is played with miniature figures, each representing one combatant, on an 8x8 grid (a chess or checkers board may be used). The object is to destroy all opposing units. The players purchase their units from force lists which describe the units of the Space Marines and the Tyranid/Genestealer Brood. Units are rated for hit points, movement, and armor. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines how the combatants move and attack.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Open Drafting

name: Adventure Club
description:
“Players are modern-day, rich, athletic, leisure-minded adventurers.”

The players choose one of three traits for their adventurer: “World Class Athlete”, “Filthy Rich”, or “No Responsibilities.” The players collect and play resource cards allowing them to complete adventures such as “Running of the Bulls”, “Sahara Marathon”, “Ski the South Pole”, and “Suborbital Space Flight.”

The game ends when there are no Adventure cards left, at which point the player with the highest Victory Point total wins.

name: Adventurers
description:
A game of archaeological adventuring set in the 1930’s and 1940’s. Save the damsel, defeat the villain, and recover the ancient artifact before your adversaries can!

The players choose their adventurer type from a variety of professions, such as Archaeologist, Daredevil Pilot, Occult Expert, Private Investigator, or Soldier of Fortune. Each profession confers a special benefit.

Through drawing and playing cards, the players conduct research, travel to exotic locations, acquire weapons and other useful items, and attempt to escape dangerous encounters.

To win the game, be the first player to visit five locations, the last of which must be an Ancient location, which represents the successful recovery of the ancient relic.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Adventures in Talislanta
description: A fantasy adventure boardgame based on the Talislanta role-playing game. The game is played on a randomly constructed map made out of an 11x11 array of map tiles. Each player randomly chooses a character from a deck of around forty character cards. The players journey around the map, facing deadly encounters, and attempt to complete adventures (tests of strength). If a player’s character is killed, a new character is drawn and the player continues the game with that character. The object of the game is to be the first player to successfully complete five adventures.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Adventures in Wonderland
description: A card game for two or more players based on the book “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” by Lewis Carroll. The game is played using a deck containing Character Cards, Location Cards, Action Cards, and Modifier Cards. The object of the game is to wake up the opposing players by increasing their Insanity Totals. In addition to the standard set of cards, the rules provide a second set of cards based on “Through the Looking Glass.”

name: American Game Hunter
description: A simple hunting themed card game. The object of the game is to be the first player to make a kill. To do so, a player must acquire two Technique cards and one each of the Weapon, Habitat, Prey, and Spoiler cards.

name: Anthill
description: The players control rival ant colonies. To win the game you must destroy all rival opposing colonies. The game is played on an 8x8 grid, such as a chess board, that represents the backyard of a suburban house. Terrain is randomly placed and consists of sweet spots (food), concrete slabs, dry spots, and covered spots. Each player starts with a colony of ten ants in a corner of the board. A deck of cards is used to resolve combat. Card play also permits a colony to nest to generate more ant units.

name: Arabia
description:
A simple boardgame of high adventure in the mysterious lands of Arabia. The game is played on a square track with 10 spaces per side (for a total of 36 spaces) with the corners designated as Baghdad, Mecca, Medina, and the Silk Road. All other spaces are empty and large enough to hold one of the Adventure Cards. The Adventure Deck and discard pile sit in the center of the board.

Players travel around the board acquiring treasures (and trying to steal them from other players). The players also face challenges. If a player fails a challenge, the Challenge Card is placed on the space the player occupies and any player landing on the card must confront the challenge.

The game ends when a player is required to draw a card but there are no cards left in the Adventure Deck. Victory is determined based on the acquisition of Fortune, Fame, and Faith points.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Arcology
description:
A Gin Rummy influenced card game based on the philosophies and theories of the famous architect Paolo Soleri.

The custom deck is composed of five types of cards: Arcology, Structure, Energy, Theory, and Philosophy. The objective of the game is to be the first to build three Arcologies.

A player builds an Arcology by playing a meld of one Arcology card and two of each other type of card. Certain cards count as two cards when building certain Arcologies.

name: Army of Darkness Skirmish
description:
It’s good versus “med”-evil in this game of combat based on the Evil Dead film Army of Darkness.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Each player controls 18 creatures, represented by miniatures or counters, which are based on characters from the film (such as Ash, Evil Ash, Archers, and Deadite Warriors.) The good guys also have the Deathcoaster car at their disposal.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of the opposing units. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Fighting, Horror, Medieval, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Arc Gammon
description: A two-player game in the spirit of Backgammon. The game is played on a ring of twelve round spaces numbered one to twelve. Two white six-sided dice and a colored six-sided die are required for play. Each player requires a different colored set of twelve tokens that are capable of being stacked. The game provides several victory conditions: capture all of your opponent’s tokens, occupy any nine spaces, occupy any five spaces in a row, or occupy a defined set of four spaces (12-1-2-3, or 3-4-5-6, or 6-7-8-9, or 9-10-11-12.)

name: Artifact Core Rules
description:
“Original Victorian Themed version of the WarpQuest Gaming System. Each player controls a party of adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters trying to be the first to get some, relic, artifact, or treasure and bring it back.”

The game is played on a single winding path of connected squares, generally 30 spaces long. The action is driven by cards drawn from the scenario specific deck. The mapboard path and card deck are subdivided to represent different stages of the adventure. Typically one deck is used for the first fifteen spaces on the path -- the second deck is used for the last fifteen spaces on the path.

The scenarios available for Artifact include: Depths of the Earth (first travel through the Earth’s crust, then adventure in the Lost World of dinosaurs), Mummys Tomb (first travel down the Nile, then explore the tomb searching for the treasure of the pharaoh), Lost Continent of Atlantis (travel deep below the sea by submarine, then explore the lost continent in diving suits searching for the Pearl Trident), and The Shadow of a Dark God (a Cthulhu style scenario where the players first investigate a friend’s death, then search a cult temple).

name: Austin Powers
description: A shagadelic card game based on the Austin Powers movies. The game is played with two decks containing 50 cards each, a Groovy deck for the International Man of Mystery and an Evil Deck for Doctor Evil. There are five card types in each deck. In the Groovy Deck, these are: Austin Power, Special Agent, Catch Phrases, Spy Stuff and Groovy Moves. In the Evil Deck, the card types are: Doctor Evil, Hench Men, Evil Equipment, Diabolical Schemes and One Liners. The first player to accumulate 10 or more Mojo Points wins.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Avatar Adventures
description:
A card game based on the character of Avatar, The Last Airbender.

“Each player is trying to help the Avatar complete Quests on their own turn and preventing their opponents from completing quests on their turns. Victory: The Player with the most Quest Points when the game ends is the winner. Game End: The game ends the turn after there are no cards left in the deck. Quest Points: Each card in your Victory Pile is worth 1 Quest Point.”
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Away Team Skirmish
description:
“Abstract skirmish level combat with Star Trek theme. Each figure represents a single man (or alien). Victory: You win if you kill all opposing men.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Each player starts with a team of eight men. Miniatures or counters, which are marked by race and officer type, are used to represent the combatants. Statistics are given for four types of teams: Federation, Klingon, Romulan, and Borg. Each player chooses one type of team at the start of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

name: Barbarella
description:
A card game inspired by the events and characters of the movie Barbarella.

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are six suits in the deck, each with nine cards. The suites are Barbarella, Allies, Foes, Places, Events, and Things. The players score points by playing six-card combos. Scoring is as follows: one point for three pairs, two points for two three-of-a-kinds, three points for a flush, and four points for a straight which includes one card from each of the six suits. The first player to reach ten points wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play

name: Battle for Naboo
description:
“Battle between the Gungan & Federation Armies on Naboo. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe (Episode I). Each figure represents a Leader, Vehicle, or Unit of Troops. Victory: If the Shield Generator Beast is destroyed, the Robots win. The game ends automatically after you go through the deck twice when young Anakin destroys the Federation Carrier Ship, which shuts down all the Robots. The Gungan player wins at this time.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. The Gungan Units include Jar Jar Binks, Gungan Generals, Shieldmen, Slingers, Cavalry, Catapults, and a Shield Beast. The Federation Units include Hover Tanks, Battle Droids, and Droidekas. Each unit is rated for hit points, movement distance, and attack range. The players draw a hand of cards from a common custom deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Dick Tracy Files
description: A card game based on the famous comic strip and movie detective. The game is played with a custom card deck composed of Crime Cards (Criminal, Felony, and Escape Cards) and Law Cards (Dick Tracy, Helper, Investigation, and Pursuit Cards.) The first player to solve three cases is the winner. To solve a case you have to form one of seven types of combos by taking turns drawing and discarding cards.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Doctor Strange
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on the comic book character Doctor Strange. One player is the forces of good. The other player is the forces of evil. Victory: If, for 2 turns in a row, starting on turn 10, a player has no viable Characters in play, his opponent wins.”

A viable character is one of the player’s character cards that is not Killed, Incapacitated, Exiled, or Captured. Each viable character may make one attack each turn, resolved by die roll and card play. A successful attack can result in the attacker gaining control over one of the opposing player’s character. Characters may also be captured and rescued.

"The Deck: Players share a common deck. Card Types include: Characters, Companions, Locations, Items, Modifiers, Powers, Attacks, Events."

name: Escape from LA
description:
“Solo card, dice & board game. Based on the Movie of the same name. Take on the role of Snake Plisskin.”

The game consists of seventeen scenes based on events and characters from the film. To aid in advancing through the scenes, a gameboard with a track of seventeen spaces can be drawn. The player gains cards at various stages. There are four different card types. Each type of card gives a bonus to a different type of die roll.

“Victory: Escape & Activate the Electro-Magnetic Pulse in the last Step. Losing: You lose if you ever get killed, or you do not get the antidote in 10 hours.”
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Fantasy Fliers
description:
“Miniatures rules for aerial skirmishes. All combatants (Fliers) include a mount with usually one rider.”

The game features a diverse assortment of aerial combatants, all rated in two classes: Speed and Maneuverability. The Speed rating determines maximum speed, acceleration and deceleration rates, climb and dive rates, and modifiers for dodging and initiative. The Maneuverability rating determines turning rate, dodging ability, and initiative bonus. A wide variety of attack types are provided for: Spell, Poison, Ram, Grab, Petrification/Paralyze, Stun, Web/Net, Mesmerize, Fear, Smoke/Gas, and Fire/Acid Attacks.

With over fifty Mounts described in the game, Fantasy Fliers allows for just about every type of aerial combat you could think of – from bees, wasps, and butterflies to magic carpets, flying skulls, biplanes, and Pegasus.

name: Gearhead Skirmish
description:
“2 Armies of Wind-up toys duke it out. Based on an old video game. Victory: Players get 1 point every time a toy goes off their opponent’s side of the board. The game ends when the counter pile is empty and there are no toys left on the board (or no toy has been able to move in 5 turns.) The player with the most points wins the game.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Six and eight-sided dice are required. There are twelve wind-up toys in the game, each with its own counter.

At the beginning of the game, all of the toy counters are placed in a cup or face down in a pile. At the start of a player’s turn, a toy counter is drawn and placed at that player’s end of the board. Each of the player's toys moves once. The type of move each piece can make is determined by a die roll.

name: Freddy vs. Jason Skirmish
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on the Supernatural Horror Movies. One player is Freddie, the other is Jason.”

The game uses a custom deck containing ten types of cards: Location, Victim, Attack, Fire Attack, Death Blow Attack, Trap, Escape, Heal, Inspiration and Special cards. You win the game by reducing your opponent’s Hit Points to zero.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Dumbledore's Army
description:
“Based on the battle at the end of Harry Potter & the Order of the Phoenix. Battle between Dumbledore & his Followers vs Voldemort & his Death Eaters. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single wizard. Victory: The Dumbledore player wins if Voldemort is ‘defeated’. The Voldemort player wins if Dumbledore or Harry is ‘defeated’.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the wizards. The Dumbledore player has twelve wizards and the Voldemort player has thirteen. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Dragon Slayers
description:
“One player takes the role of the Dragon. The other player takes the role of the Slayer (the adventuring party trying to slay the dragon). There are 2 decks: The Dragon Deck. The Slayer Deck.”

The Slayer player starts with up to eight randomly selected characters and/or artifacts. The Slayer plays cards to attack the dragon which the Dragon player may attempt to block. The Dragon player then has the opportunity to attack one or more members of the Slayer Party.

“Victory: If the Dragon is reduced to 0 or less Hit Points the Slayers win. If all party members are killed, the Dragon wins. The Dragon has 10 hit points. Party Members (Slayers: Heroes & Men-at-Arms) have 1 hit point each. Each unblocked attack by the Dragon will kill one party member. Unblocked attacks by Slayers cause 1 or more hit points of damage to the Dragon.”
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Print & Play

name: Dragonlance Companions
description:
“Takes place 300+ years after the great cataclysm in the world of Krynn. Guide the Companions of the Lance in their exploration of the ruins of Xak Tsaroth to retrieve the Disks of Mishakal needed to defeat Takhisis, the Queen of Darkness. Players share a common deck.”

Each turn the player is seeking to capture a foe by playing a foe card along with Hero and Aid cards having a force value higher than the Foe card. The captured Foe card is placed in the player’s Victory Pile and the Hero and Aid Cards go in the discard pile.
“Game End: The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck and everyone passes their turn without capturing a Foe card. Victory: The player with the highest Force total in his Victory pile wins the game.”

name: Baseball Outs
description:
A baseball game played using dice and cards and incorporating the general rules of baseball.

The players draw two cards each turn and may hold a hand of up to seven cards. After the card draw, two six-sided dice are rolled to determine the result of each “at bat.” The die roll result may be modified by the play of Hit, Batter, Effect, and Pitch Cards. After the batter’s fate is determined, and the base runners advanced (if necessary), Fielding Cards may be played. The deck also includes Automatic Result cards which may be played in lieu of the batting roll before the dice are rolled.

name: Battle Royale
description:
An abstract battle game played on Strategic and Tactical Boards. The object of the game is to capture the opponent’s castle.

The Tactical Board is a 6x6 grid containing six randomly placed terrain obstacles which block movement. The Strategic Board is a 7x7 grid. The corner squares and center square on the Strategic Board are Towns, and the center square in each player’s back row is a Castle.

Both players start with six Armies on the strategic map, one located in the Castle and the other five in the surrounding squares. When opposing Armies occupy the same space on the Strategic Board, they are immediately moved to the Tactical Board for battle. A partition is placed in the center of the Tactical Board so that the battling forces may be set up in secret. The Tactical Battle concludes when one side has no pieces left, or if no pieces can move, or if no further captures can be made by either side, or if ten turns elapse without a capture being made.

Players earn gold from occupied towns. Gold may be used to recruit (purchase) new units.

name: BattleTech Skirmish
description:
A tactical boardgame set in the Battletech Universe. Each player controls a group of Battlemechs. The object of the game is to capture the opposing leader.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. The game provides specifications for forty-two different Battlemechs. The statistics provided include hit points, movement, jump capability, and damage inflicted at close, medium and long range.

Each player assembles a force of Battlemechs with up to 50 hit points. Movement and combat are governed by the cards. The players draw hands of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Berserker
description:
Inspired by Fred Saberhagen's Berserker series.

“Human fleet vs a Berserker Ship. Abstract skirmish level Ship combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: Destroy the opposing fleet.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. The Human Fleet player has a force of sixteen ships against the single Berserker ship. Each ship is rated for hit points, speed, and attack range. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Biker Brawl
description:
Rival motorcycle gangs face off in a duel to the death.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Each player has eight bikers in his gang. Bikers come in three different types: Leaders, Veterans, and Gang Members. Each gang has an assortment of motorcycles, guns, knives, and tool boxes to distribute among the members. The game is driven by a custom card deck. The players draw hands of cards from the deck, and card play determines when units may move or attack.

name: Biomechanoids
description:
A card game based on the fantasy creations of artist H.R. Giger.

“Players raise armies of Biomechanoids to destroy each other with. Victory: Reduce your opponent to zero hits. Each player starts with 20 hits.”

The game is played using a deck of over 120 cards, which come in seven types: Location, Biomechanoid, Feature, Artifact, Action, Reaction, and Destiny.

name: Birthright Conquest
description: “Card game for 2 players. Set in the AD&D Birthright Campaign Setting. One player controls the Armies of Good. The other player controls the Armies of Evil. Victory: Destroy all your opponents. To destroy an opponent, you must: Reduce your opponents Realm deck to zero cards. Then eliminate all his Realms in play.”

name: Buccaneers
description:
“Boarding Action between two Pirate ships. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Captain.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the pirates, which come in five types: Captains, First Mates, Bullyboys, Sailors, and Sharpshots. The game uses a custom deck of cards which is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Bug Out
description:
A strategy game with a bug theme.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Twenty-eight Bug counters are placed on all of the squares around the edges of the board. There are four each of seven types of Bugs: Bee, Ant, Ladybug, Grass Hopper, Beetle, Spider, and Dragon Fly. Each type of Bug moves differently. The players take turns moving uncontrolled Bugs. When a player moves a Bug, one of the player’s Control Markers is placed on it. If you line up three Bugs under your control in a row (orthogonal, not diagonal), then you score one point and your control makers are removed from the Bugs. The winner is the first player to accumulate seven points.

name: Cabal
description:
A game based on the role-playing game Mage: The Ascension.

Each player controls a Cabal of Mages. A player keeps two hands of cards simultaneously: a Foe Hand and a Spell Hand.

To win the game, you must meet all of the following conditions: One or more of your Mages must ascend to the 10th Level (Oracle); you must establish a Chantry (control one or more Nodes); and all Foes in your Territory must be at 5th level or less.

The game components are: Four card decks (Mage, Spell, Attribute, and Foe Decks), Tokens (to track Wounds, Experience, Talismans, Transformations, and Conversions), ten and six-sided dice, and a pencil and paper.

name: Calcala
description:
“2-4 Player Mancala Variant using a square 36 pit board. Capture the Most stones by the end of the Game. The Game ends when there are only 6 or less stones remaining on the board. The board is composed of 36 Pits (spaces) laid out in a 6 by 6 Grid. Use glass beads or whatever (seeds, nuts, pebbles) for Pieces. Players share a common set of Stones. Each player has his own pile (cup) where he keeps the Stones he has captured. Setup: Place 2 Stones in each Pit. The least gracious player goes first.”

The rules provide four alternatives to the standard setup: Short Game (1 Stone in each pit), Long Game (3 Stones in each pit), Double Dutch (3 Stones in every other pit), and Half Dutch (2 Stones in every other pit).

name: Car Chase
description:
“Simulates a car chase between the Law and a Fugitive. Winning: The Fugitive wins if the Law does not catch him at the end of 7 turns.”

The game uses a custom deck with seven types of cards: Investigation, Fugitive, Chase, Escape, Capture, and Location. At the start of each turn the players fill their hands up to ten cards, with the option to discard and redraw up to five. The remainder of the turn consists of up to three phases of card play - the Search Phase, Chase Phase, and Escape Phase.

The turn ends with any Phase that the Law player loses. The Law player must win a series of all three Phases to capture the Fugitive and win the game.

name: Carny
description:
“Players are setting up their Game Booths at the Fair. Card game for 2+ players. Carnival: A cooperative business arrangement between independent showmen, ride owners and concessionaires to present outdoor amusement for the public. Carny or Carney: Someone who works in a carnival. The term is also applied to the carnival itself. Game Length: Each turn = 1 day. Before play, players decide on the duration of the Fair from 5 to 20 days. Winning: The Player with the most money at the end of the Fair wins.”

Discard and draw cards to attempt to form melds. Earn money by playing up to two melds each turn. Increase the value of your melds by playing good Event Cards. Decrease the value of your opponent’s melds by adding bad Neighbor or bad Event cards to them.

name: Challenge of the Superfriends
description:
Based on the 1978 season of the Superfriends TV cartoon.

One player controls the Superfriends (Justice League), the other player controls the Legion of Doom. The game uses a custom card deck for each player. Each deck includes Character Cards and Plot Cards.

To win a hand a player must play Plot and Character cards having a higher total Power Value than the cards played by the opposing player. The first player to win a total of seven hands wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: City of Heroes Skirmish
description:
“Battle between Superheroes & Villains. Takes place in the City of Heroes Universe. Each figure (unit) represents a single Hero or Villain. Victory: Destroy all opposing Units.”

A non-collectable game based on the City of Heroes CCG. The game is played on a 12x12 hex map. The Hero player picks six Heroes and the Villain player picks one Villain group. The players draw hands of cards from a shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

name: Civil War Poker
description: A poker flavored betting game played with a custom deck having five suits. Each suit has ten cards. There are also two wild cards in the deck. The winning hands, from lowest to highest, are a pair (suited), two pairs, three of a kind, full house, four of a kind, straight, and five of a kind. Ties are broken by comparing suits: Infantry beats Cavalry, Cavalry beats Artillery, Artillery beats Infantry, Generals beat all other suites.

name: Clinical Studies
description:
“Players are rival medical scientists trying to out-publish each other. Objective: The player to accumulate the most Publisher Points at the end of the game wins. The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck.”

There are six kinds of cards in the deck: Study, Methodology, Statistics, References, Journal, Flaw, and Research. To publish a study, a player must play a Study Card and a Journal Card plus one or more Methodology, Statistics, and References Cards. The player receives one publisher point for each card played when publishing a study.

name: Cyberiad
description:
Cyberiad: Exploits of the Constructors is a card game based on the book The Cyberiad by Stanislaw Lem.

“Setting: A medieval universe populated by sentient robots. The constructors are prolific inventors with almost god-like powers. Each player takes the role of a Constructor, trying to gain the Most fame. Victory: The player with the most Fame points at the end of the game wins. Any player that accumulates 50 or more Fame points automatically wins. Any player that accumulates 20 or more Trouble points automatically loses. Game End: The game ends when one player has claimed 7 Sally cards or the Deck is empty when a player starts his turn.”

name: Da Vinci Poker
description:
“Poker variant with a Leonardo da Vinci theme. Players share a Unique 52 card deck. There are 5 Suites: Art, Earth Science, Humanities, Engineering, Life Science. Each suite represents a field of knowledge that Leonardo contributed to. The 5 Suites comprise 50 of the cards. There are 2 Additional 'Renaissance Man' cards that act as Wild cards.”

Each card is marked with four pieces of information: Suit, Rank (from 1 to 10), Name and Details (the latter two provide unique Da Vinci flavor for each card).

name: Death Racers
description:
“Mad Max style post-apocalyptic gang-warfare road combat.”

Each player starts with a random assortment of six vehicles, each of which has a random piece of equipment (mostly weaponry of some sort) which can be used a random number of times as determined by the roll of a six-sided die. The road is a track 100 spaces long with randomly distributed obstacles.

One player is designated as the Slow Gang, the other player is designated as the Fast Gang. The Slow Gang vehicles start at one end of the track and must try to reach the other end. The Fast Gang player may place his vehicles on any space on the track. The Slow Gang player wins by getting at least three vehicles to the opposite end of the track, otherwise the Fast Gang player wins.

name: Deity
description:
“Players assume the roles of certain lesser Demigods. Each demigod begins with a small band of worshipers. Gain power by building temples and helping your population grow. Crush your enemy’s populations with acts of god and the armies of the faithful. The last remaining immortal is the one true Deity. Objective: Destroy all of your opponent armies, populations, and temples.”

The game is played on a 10x10 or 12x12 hex map filled with terrain counters placed by random draw at the start of each game. A deck of Miracle Cards provides the players with the ability to either benefit their own forces or harm enemy forces. The number of Miracle Cards a player receives each turn depends on the number of temples controlled by the player.

name: Denizens of the Deep
description:
“When Atlantis sunk into the sea, the only survivors who could still occupy the city were the Mermen and the Tritons. Even then, the inhabitants of Atlantis were still plagued with numerous enemies. The evil and powerful Sea Witch has summoned all the enemies of Atlantis together to destroy the city. The Sea King and his faithful allies stand ready to repel the monstrous horde.”

One player plays the Sea King, the other player plays the Sea Witch. The object of the game is to kill the opposing commander. Each side has a different allocation of undersea forces, including Mermen, Whales, Giant Sea Turtles, Sharks, Eels, Rays, and Pirhana. Some units are able to use magic. Each unit is rated for Attack Dice, Defense, Movement, and a Hide Factor. The game is played on a hex map filled with deep and shallow water terrain types.

name: Desperate Housewives Card Game
description:
“Each player takes the role of a ‘Desperate Housewife.’ Players compete to get the best Husbands, Houses, Jobs, Kids, etc. Victory: The Player with the Highest Total Card Score at the end of the game wins. Add up the score for each card you have in play. Game End: The Game ends when the player who draws the last card in the deck ends his turn.”

The custom deck includes over eighty cards, including cards representing housewives, houses, men, children, events and ‘modifier’ cards which either improve or degrade other cards.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Destiny
description: A fantasy adventure game where the players compete to be the first to obtain five treasures. Each player takes on the role of a randomly drawn character, ranging from a Thief or Jester to a King or Emperor. Each hand the players compete to win a treasure by trying to play cards which will have the highest combined Destiny total.

name: Diamond Traders
description: The players share a common 60 card deck. The deck is made up of five suits, each of which has twelve cards. The object is to have the largest point score after four turns. Points are scored by revealing “Stone” combos containing one card from each of the five suits: cut, color, clarity, karat, and kind. Five variants are included, mostly intended to produce longer or shorter games.

name: Disciple Lords
description: “Card game for 2-4 players. Based on the Disciples Computer Strategy Games. Players Share one Common Deck. Each player has a unique Race Deck. The common deck has 6 types of cards: Locations, Advances, Items, Potions, Events, Treasure. Each race deck contains 5 types of cards: Leaders, Summons, Followers, Spells, Buildings. Each player keeps 2 hands: 1 Common deck hand & 1 Race deck hand. Major Victory: Capture all of your opponents’ Cities. Minor Victory: The game ends when any players Race deck runs out. The player controlling the most cities at that point wins.”

name: Dodeca
description: A game played on a 10×10 grid using dice as pieces. The game requires ten four-sided dice, four six-sided dice, four eight-sided dice, and two ten-sided dice (the Dodecas.) The object of the game is to capture both of your opponent’s Dodecas. Before the dice are placed on the board, they are rolled and placed with the resulting numbers showing. A player can take one of two actions each turn: move a die a number of spaces equal to the number on its top face (each type of die moves differently) and change the number showing on the die by +/- one, or reroll a die to reset its face-up number.

name: Dodge Ball
description: A game played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Each player needs six pawns or checkers, etc., to represent the dodge ball team members. These are placed on the back rows of the board at the start of the game. Skills are rolled for each of the players (there are six: Dodge, Fast, Aim, Catch, Strong, and Quick). One piece on each side is designated the Team Captain, who receives a second skill. The game is played using a custom deck of cards. The cards are played to move a player or throw the ball.

name: Fantasy Fight Club
description:
“Combat between 2 opposing fantasy warbands. Game progresses in 2 stages: Recruit Stage. Battle Stage.”

In the Recruit Stage, the players create their warbands by receiving a random selection of ten warriors to which they must assign their random assortments of weapons and armor cards.

The game is played with five decks of cards -- the Warrior, Weapon, Armor, Spell and Fight Decks.

name: Fantasy Fighters
description:
“Card game of Fantasy combat.”

The game is played with a custom deck of fifty cards. Combat consists of playing card combinations which represent specific attacks the fighters can carry out. The fighters also have combinations which can be played in defense. The game comes with statistics for three sample fighters.

name: Sgt Bilko
description:
Spin and move to operate "Bilko Promotions", acquire the most money and avoid the perils of army life. This game is based on the '50s TV show Sgt Bilko starring Phil Silvers. The game lasts until twelve 'promotions' are played, and players can bankrupt out of the game.

Contents:

circular board
blue cards
yellow cards representing 'Bilko Productions'
play money
spinner
4 x playing counters
categories: Economic, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Wizard Skirmish
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two rival Wizards. Each figure represents a Wizard or a Summoned Creature. Victory: Reduce the opposing Wizard to zero Hit Points."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units.

Each player starts with just their Wizard on the board. Summon Cards are played to summon monsters which are then controlled by that Wizard. The Wizards battle by using Spell Cards to attack their opponent as well as by making attacks with the summoned monsters. Card play determines how units may move, attack, and defend.

name: TO-TO tärningsspel
description: Horse racing game, where you roll 3 different dice, which indicates which horse you move and which way (forwards or backwards). Each player has a horse of a particular colour, and if yours finish first, you have won the game or that race, if you have decided to play several races.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pluck-it
description:
Carefully remove feathers without disturbing the eggs.
The player with the least number of eggs in their compartment is the winner!

name: Letter Ladder
description: Collect 'runs' of sequential letters from hand and available draw cards. Helps teach the alphabet.

name: Live Action Risk (Lark)
description: Live Action Risk (Lark) enables groups of all sizes to experience Risk in a simplified form. A party game of allegiances, war, and conquering other countries, Lark can be played inside or outside with each player representing a country of the world. Players battle each other with d6's, with the winner conquering and controlling the vanquished country. As a ruling world power, your vassals have to comply with your every whim. But watch out! If you lose a combat, you become the lackey of another world leader!
categories: Dice, Negotiation, Party Game, Political, Real-time, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Team-Based Game

name: Lotto
description: A telephone dial points to the brightly coloured picture which the child may "discard" if he happens to have the same picture in front of him. The child uses the dial to turn the colours indicated by the 2 dice he has thrown. If the arrow on the dial points to a picture that corresponds to a picture which the child has in front of him on the table, the child may turn it over. The first player to succeed in turning over the pre-determined number of cards is the winner. The game consists of a telephone dial, 72 cards and 2 colored dice.

name: Medieval Keep
description:
"Multiplayer card game or Solo rules."

"Each player controls a small town in a medieval setting. Every turn players build structures and hire defenders to protect their town. Some cards are used to send invaders and disasters to destroy your opponent's towns."

The custom card deck contains three types of cards: Structures, Invaders, and Disasters. Revenue gained from structures can be used to purchase Defenders ranging from guards and swordsmen to longbow men and mounted knights.

"Object: Have the most defenders and structures at the end of the game. Each defender and structure is worth 1 victory point. The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck. In a multi-player game, the game ends if all but one player's town is destroyed." In a solitaire game you win by getting through the deck.

name: Ypres
description:
"Card game of Western Front Battle 1915 (solo or 2 players)"

Each player has two custom decks, Officer and Unit Decks. The players also share a common Modifier Deck. Each player also uses ten-sided dice as casualty markers to track their troop casualties. Ten terrain markers used to track victory points.

"The side that loses his troops loses the game. The player that first possesses 10 Terrain markers wins the game."
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, World War I

name: Swiss Family Robinson
description:
"Solo Board, Dice, and Card Game. You control the Swiss Family Robinson. A Group of Pirates is attacking your Rocky Redoubt."

The game uses a chess board or other 8x8 grid and a set of custom cards. Six pieces are used to represent the family members, classified as three grown men, two women, and a child. Sixteen pawns are used to represent the pirates.

Each pirate moves 0-2 spaces toward the family members each turn, as determined by random die roll. The cards are played to cause the family members to attack the pirates.
"Victory: Drive off all of the Pirates and keep the Family Members from being captured."
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Pirates

name: Spanish Armada
description:
"Solo card game using a regular deck of cards. Based on the Failure of the Spanish Armada to invade England in 1588. The Armada had 122 Ships. The English 66. The English sank 2 Spanish Ships and were able to disperse the Armada. The dispersed Armada drifted into the North Sea and had to circle around Ireland in treacherous weather to return home. On the journey home 39 transports foundered or ran aground."

The deck is split into two halves, the red half (Spanish Armada) and the black half (English Squadrons). Each turn has two phases, a Straggler Phase and an Engagement Phase. The player must use his English raider ships to disperse Spanish stragglers, which are then placed in the player's Victory Pile. The victory conditions set the level of success or failure based on the number of cards in the Victory Pile after the Spanish Armada Deck has been exhausted.

name: Puppy Play!
description:
This is a card game using different breeds of puppies as suits and cats as wild cards. It also includes a spinner with numbers from 1 to 10. The instructions contain rules for 5 different games:
No More Puppies
Pile of Puppies
Puppy Rummy
Puppy Memory (with a twist)
Plenty of Puppies!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Memory

name: Galactic Expansion
description: A light counter-based conquer game, Galactic Expansion is a game where each player has a sector map (the basic set comes with 3). Each player's turn is split into 5 phases: Economy (Receive resource for colony), Intel (Espionage, Incite Rebellion, Recon, or Sabotage), Combat (dice-based with modifiers), Deployment, End (Expand or Fortify). The winner is the last person standing.

name: Beat Your Neighbours
description: This is a "war" type card game published during the 1950s and 1960s by various publishers. The deck consists of 36 cards with colorful pictures on them. The cards are dealt around evenly to all players. Players do not look at their cards. Play starts with one player turning over his top card, then the next player turns over a card. If a "put" card is turned over, the next player has to turn over a specified number of cards. If no additional "put" card is turned over then the player with the first "put" card wins all face up cards. Eventually, one player will possess all cards and be the winner.
publishers: Arrow Games Ltd, Clifford Toys, Patterson Blick, Tower Press

name: Íslenska fuglaspilið
description: A simple educational game about Icelandic birds. The game comes with a CD with the calls of 30 birds. Rules for three kinds of games are included, Sound Bingo, Photo Bingo and Memory. The bingo cards have photos of 9 birds each and the players either listen to bird calls or are shown photos of a bird and try to get a bingo. Memory is simply a memory game with photos of birds.

name: Numeralogic
description: Players attempt to guess other players' secret number in the fewest number of turns through a combination of luck and logic. The game can be played by selecting anywhere from 2-5 digits depending on the time available and the ability of the players. Numeralogic is similar to Mastermind except each player selects a secret number and guessing alternates.

name: Rainbo
description:
A simple 2 player game where pieces move and capture based on a colored dot on their face.

Each player has 18 pieces of their color (White or Black) to place in secret in any arrangement of their choosing within their starting area. Each piece has a colored dot in 1 of 6 colors (Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Purple) and 1 of 3 sizes. Size and color of the dot determines rank, capturing ability and movement of each piece.

Play alternates between players and ends when one player has only one piece left on the board.

name: Fotbollsspelet
description:
Swedish trivia game with questions about football (soccer).

Before the game starts a referee is chosen. The referee reads the questions and keeps track of the score.

The questions come in 4 categories : Geography, Players, History and Misc. On a players turn a die is rolled to choose category:

1: Geography
2: Misc
3: Players
4: History
5: the Referee chooses a category
6: the player chooses a category

The first player to reach a certain score (agreed on before the game) is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Sports, Trivia

name: Der Wald der Trolle
description: The players make a tour around the village into a forest of trolls, in search for gold. Some spaces allow them to win gold rings or to take short cuts, while others force them to lose rings (unless a roll of 4), or to stop. When everyone is back home, the winner is the wealthiest player, who is not necessary the first player to have arrived.

name: Goals And Glory
description:
Goals And Glory is a game about football, power and money.
In goals and glory you are a manager for your own danish football team, and your job is to handle the press and create economical success.
Mention that the other players also have the same thing in mind.

name: Multimatch III
description:
Multimatch I and II deals with square tiles, while Multimatch III and IV concerns triangular tiles.
The box of Multimatch III contains a plastic hexagonal trail, and an acrylic set of MacMahon's Four-Color triangles. All 24 triangles are divided into three equal triangles (with short edges joining the centre to the corners) coloured with 4 colors.
The 1991 edition Kadon rulebook contains a large section of puzzles, and rules for 3 games, plus variants.

The games are:
Multimatch. Players take turns placing tiles on the hexagonal trail. The first piece placed on a border of the board determines the color of that border. Last player wins.
Outmatched. Players divide the tiles equally (face-down) and then race to assemble their group into a symmetrical shape, with tile edges matching.
Closure. The tiles are assembled into a random (but edge-matching) group. Players take turns "closing" one of the 3 colors by moving as few tiles as possible. Closing a color requires leaving no exposed edges of that color. Moves may not separate any tiles from the group.

name: Eye of the Idol
description:
The box contains all you need to seek the Eye of the Idol, a fabulous gem of legendary repute:

- a role play adventure taking you through the depths of an unmapped jungle (solo play)
- the rules for a fantasy game set on the island of the idol (for solo or group play)
The game board is built into the box and there is a small cut out area where the dice, counters and rules are stored.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Enclosure, Role Playing, Variable Phase Order

name: Hoop-La!
description:
An antique tabletop dexterity game where they players score points by flipping weighted paper cones into a 7x7 grid of scoring holes punched into an insert for the bottom half of the box. Beneath each hole is a number indicating the number of points scored for each cone that goes in the hole. The scores range from 5 points around the edges of the box to 50 points for the center hole. Each player takes a turn dropping the twelve cones onto the board one at a time. The first player to reach 100 points wins.

The components include the game box, a set of twelve weighted cones, and a set of flippers. The instructions are printed inside the lid of the 12.5 x 12.5 x 2.25 inch box. The colorful cover art depicts two clowns juggling cone shapes hats back and forth.

The publication date is an estimate.

name: Multimatch IV
description:
Multimatch I and II deals with square tiles, while Multimatch III and IV concerns triangular tiles.
The box of Multimatch IV contains a plastic hexagonal trail, and an acrylic set of Trioker four-colour triangles. Instead of showing dots, the triangles corners are coloured in plain colours.
The 1994 edition Kadon rulebook contains a large section of puzzles, and rules for 3 games, plus variants. The two first games are the same that those of Multimatch II.
Multimatch. Players take turns placing tiles on the hexagonal trail. Edges must match and the first piece must be placed on a border. Last to play wins.
Outmatched. Players share the tiles at random and then race to assemble their group into a symmetrical shape, with edges matching.
Hexagonal Match. The four solid-colour tiles are set as starter pieces. Players draw tiles and play them at their turn trying to complete a 6 tiles hexagon.

name: Merge
description: Through open auctions and raids, players buy and merge companies. When all four companies of a group are acquired, points are awarded. Play continues until all 10 sets are complete, after which the player with the most points wins.

name: Maze Craze
description:
Maze Craze is an abstract strategy game for 2 players (or for 4 playing as two teams). Each player has 8 plastic playing piece pawns initially lined up on opposite sides of an 8x8 square space game board. A turn consists of moving one playing piece one space and then following "the directions indicated by the symbol on that square." These directions include: Move Again, Advance, Safe, Defense, Return to Start. The winner is the first player to move all of one's own 8 playing pieces to the other side of the board.

Game rules are printed on one small sheet of paper, English on one side and French on the other, but the board is English only.

name: Ulataksi
description:
ULA is a Finnish acronym meaning "ultra-short wavelength" in relation to radio waves; the English equivalent is VHF or "very high frequency". The game name Ula-taxi (or Ulataksi) refers to the mode of communication between the taxi drivers and the central taxi station.

The players are taxi drivers in an unnamed city. They draw assignment cards from a deck, take money (the amount depends on which city zone they are in and where they are going) and drive to the address on the card using movement points rolled with a six-sided die. Players decide beforehand whether the game ends for example when someone has completed five assignments or when the last card in the deck has been drawn and the action completed.

During the game, the players are free to choose their routes in the streets, but movement has some restrictions: right-hand side traffic, stop signs, one-way streets etc. Violating the no-stopping sign or speed limits results in a ticket and the player loses money (for example rolling a 5 on a street with a speed limit of 3 means that the player pays 2). There are also tunnels and a ferry which give additional choices. If cars of two players collide, both go to the repair shop and the player who was moving at the time must pay a sum equivalent to the remainder of movement points on the die. Among the assignment cards there are a few cards on car maintenance, vehicle inspection and insurance which require payments and movements to appropriate locations. When the end conditions agreed upon are met, the player with the most money wins.

The rules were written in May 1968. The original game board is a paper sheet glued on a thick two-fold cardboard. The city zone payment chart is thin cardboard as are the 70 cards and the small square ferry. The game includes 100 paper banknotes with denominations of one and five. For each player there is a small plastic car and an assignment marker.

The first paragraph of the rules (translated from Finnish): "Ula-taxi is an interesting, surprising and educational game with which you will surely find entertainment. The basic idea of the game is simple, although the abundance of rules may at first feel discomforting. Once the players have become accustomed to the instructions, they will notice that the majority of them is based on general traffic regulations, the knowledge of which is nowadays common among the citizenship."

name: O! EUCLID
description:
'O! EUCLID is "an amusing and scholarly card game for ages 9-99 according to the game box top.

There are 84 cards, 6 cards for each of 14 geometric shapes: circle, equilateral triangle, square, regular pentagon, regular hexagon, regular octagon, isosceles triangle, right triangle, rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, ellipse, parabola, and hyperbola. Of the six cards, one card shows the shape and its name; one card lists 4 questions (and the true/false answers) about the shape, and four cards each with a part of the shape so that when the 4 cards are placed correctly in a 2x2 pattern, a larger version of the shape is made.

Instructions include game rules for 4 games, of which Game 2 is the basic game. In this game players win by collecting the most complete sets of 5 cards (name card plus 2x2 pattern).

There is one instruction sheet for game rules. There is also one information sheet listing Euclid's definitions of geometric shapes and describing their mathematical characteristics. The information on this second sheet is not needed for game play.
mechanics: Hand Management, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Wolli, das verlorene Schäfchen
description: In this childrens game players have to bring back lost sheep to the flock. The game comes with wooden playing pieces, a nicely drawn board and a plush sheep. Recommended for Ages 4 - 12.

name: Take five
description:
Contents: a 6×6 board, 4 series of squared pawns numbered from 1 to 9, 9 tokens for counting games, 4 chess pieces: white bishop, black bishop, black knight and black rook.

The pawns are shuffled face down and set upon the board. Then each player moves a pair of chess pieces upon the pawns and chooses one of the following option : look secretly the numbers hidden by both pawns, or look at only a single value, and capture the other pawn. The highest score wins the game

name: USA & Canada Pegboard Football
description:
Pegboard Football is based upon a wooden rectangular board with peg-holes indicating 5-yard increments that are off-set alternating every 5-Yards from one side of the field to the other, representing an entire American Football field, or the Canadian version for one when modified for that, stretching from Goal Line to Goal Line.

Components:

Board with peg-holes depicting 5-Yard increments and the GOAL lines at each end of the FIELD.
2-Pegs of different colours are utilized, to denote the current Player having possession during PLAY.
2 d6 required as a minimum, although a 3rd d6 can be used to track DOWNS.


Alternative methods for creating this:
1) Magnetized Version: With the appropriate materials at your disposal, then you can affix some reasonable DISPLAY of the Playing Field upon a metallic surface conducive to adhering the necessary components for this. That is in place of constructing it out of anything in which peg-holes were to then be used, for where this is so desired.

2) Paper/Cardstock Materials: From whatever types of this for which you have on hand, and that you can provide the required components needed in order to PLAY, then by all means use such to implement everything and ENJOY!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: Babylon 5 Empires
description:
A game of interplanetary conquest inspired by Bablyon 5.

The players control one of four races: the Centauri Empire, the Earthforce Alliance, the Minbari Federation, or the Narn Regime. The object of the game is to control over 60% of the planetary systems on the map.

Components include a space map of the zones around Babylon 5, a deck of Action Cards tailored to the theme, and sets of unit counters.

This game is a module for the Warp Empires system, the core rules are required for play.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: War Hammer Space Empires
description:
A game of science fiction conflict and conquest involving Warhammer 40,000 (Third Edition) armies.

The players take control of one of four armies: Ork, Imperial, Eldar, or Tyranid. Each army has a unique set of units. The object of the game is to capture over 80% of the planets on the map.

Components include an area movement map of space, a deck of Action Cards tailored to the theme, and sets of unit counters.

This game is a module for the Warp Empires system, the core rules are required for play.

name: Archaic Animalia
description:
"Strategy Card and Board Game for 2 to 6+ players. It is the Warm Permian-Triassic period and primitive animals are just starting to colonize the landmass of Pangaea."

Every player controls one of ten "Basic Taxons" representing a group of prehistoric animals. Each Taxon has a special ability.

The object of the game is to have the most Victory Points after every Territory on the board is occupied at least one Animal Token. Victory Points are awarded at the end of the game based on the number of Animal Tokens a player has on the board, as well as the number of Territories occupied exclusively by the player.

name: Hekumanhuippu
description:
Hekumanhuippu (engl. Climax) is an erotic game for two lovers.

Players roll a die and move on a board with separate tracks for both towards the end, the climax. The tracks consist of four kind of points: Truth, Dare, Strip and Volcano. When a player enters a point (s)he must draw a corresponding action card from a pile, read it aloud and perform the given action. Some actions are quite innocuous, some bolder (especially in the endgame).

On both tracks there are a few points where players have to take a longer reroute, throw a die again or stop (ie. perform no action). If a player throws a six, (s)he must take six steps backwards making the game last even longer.

The player to reach the end (climax) first is the winner. (S)he may choose the prize or players can decide it together beforehand.

Contents:
-Game board
-47 Truth cards
-45 Dare cards
-12 Strip cards
-19 Volcano cards
-Two pawns
-A die
-Rules printed at the bottom of the box
mechanics: Acting, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: Das Verlorene Amulett
description:
Das Verlorene Amulett is a family game where players try to decode hieroglyphics and create complete sentences. Players travel in old Egypt to search the for the amulet, which helps them decipher the meaning of the cryptic codes. To gain the amulet, and decode the graphics, players answer questions that require both mathematical and logical thinking. When a correct solution is given, the player gets an Egyptian hieroglyphic tile. Players form words from their hieroglyphics, and the words are combined from all players form together a sentence.

The rulebook includes all the questions on the cards plus their answers, making the game easily playable in English.

name: Response
description: The game requires each player to provide a one-word response to clues given. These clues, which are similar to those given in crossword puzzles, are given to the player from a selected card in the forms of definitions, statements, or other words. When a player responds to the clue correctly he/she places a colored marker over the letter representing that response on his/her section of the board. When a player has completely covered his/her playing area he/she is the winner.

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition des stars
description:
This is a card set expansion to Trivial Pursuit containing 500 questions about stars of the following categories:
Tv
movies
way of life
advertising
songs
jet set
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Buck Fever
description:
• Roll the dice to determine where you will start your hunt.
• After reaching your hunting destination, begin your hunt by drawing a card.
• Each card will tell you what you have to roll to hit your deer.
• Just like a real hunt, the difficulty in getting the deer is determined by distance and type of weapon.
• The larger bucks are harder to get, but earn you more points!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Environmental, Sports
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Xanth Quest
description:
"Board and Card game for 2+ players. Based on the Xanth series by Piers Anthony." Particularly inspired by the first Xanth novel, A Spell for Chameleon.

The game is played on a track 63 spaces long, with each space being large enough to hold a card. The middle space is the Gap Chasm. Each time a player lands on an empty space, a card is drawn. A Challenge Card represents an encounter or event that must be resolved. A Location Card is left on the space occupied by the player who drew the card.

"Victory: Be the first player to get your pawn to the end space and then back to the Starting space. (It’s a race game.) This represents a quest involving a trek across the dangerous wilderness of Xanth."

name: Yellow Submarine
description:
"Board & Dice game for 2-4+ players. Based on the Song/Movie by the Beatles."

"The Board is a psychedelic winding track of 39 spaces." Ten spaces are marked as Song Spaces. A player landing on a Song Space must draw a Song Card and sing the song. Nine other spaces are Adventure Spaces named after items in the movie. A player landing on one of these spaces must roll the die and move backwards that many spaces.

"Winning: Make it to the End Space & sing (Everybody now…) All You Need is Love."
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music

name: Warrior Races of Mars
description:
"Wargame. Set piece battles. Simulates battles between the six main warrior races of Mars during the Era of Discontent. During this turbulent period, factions of all races fought with and against each other. Welcome to Mars."

The game is played on a hex map and uses up to twenty types of terrain/settlements: Barren, Impassable, Flats, Forest, Swamp, Hills, Caves, Mountains, Jungles, Psiwell, Desert, Fortifications, Dojo, Vehicle Factory, Weapons Factory, Training Grounds, Farms, Temple, City, and Ruins.

There are six races in the game: Green, Red, White, Blue, Yellow, and Black Martians. Each Martian race has warbands and leaders. The warbands of each race are rated from 0 to 6 in the following attributes: Speed, Small Arms, Surprise, Hand to Hand, Armor, Artillery, Numbers, Psionics, and Morale.

Variant Warband ratings are included for special units such as Red Commandos, Yellow Wasp Riders, Blue Mob, Black Warlocks, and Green Beetle Tanks.

name: Warbah
description:
"Fantasy conquest. Characterized by Gold and bookkeeping. Explore, expand your territory, collect gold, find artifacts, cast spells, raise armies, gain experience, send out spies, crush your enemies."

Each player starts with a capitol city, a hero, a wandering wizard, one to ten gold, and one to ten of the four basic troop units: Warriors, Archers, Cavalry, and Catapults.

The game includes rules permitting espionage and alliances.

name: Superhero Slugfest
description:
"Smash! Blam! Pow! Quick & dirty tactical rules for Superhero combat."

The game is played on a hex map with spaces large enough to accommodate miniature figures.

Superheroes are rated for Attack, Damage, Defend, Hits, Speed, and Range (hand to hand). Numerous powers and special abilities are also defined in the rules.

Stats for eleven superhero teams are given. "A typical team will have four members and a theme."

"The basic scenario: Each side picks or creates a team and they proceed to beat each other to a pulp."
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Superhero Slugfest Card Combat
description:
A card game of superhero combat. Each player uses a custom deck of cards which represents all of the members and powers of one Superhero Team.

Each deck has forty cards to represent the four team members. There are ten cards for each Superhero, five Character Cards and five Ability Cards. Each card has a force value of 1 to 5. A player tries to knock out opposing Superheroes by playing cards with a higher total force value than those played by the opposing player.

"You win if you KO all of your opponents Superheroes."
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fighting

name: Tlachtli
description:
"Board & Card game for two players. Based on the Aztec sport of the same name."

The game is played on a 13x7 grid. There are three pawns, one representing the ball and two representing blockers. The movement of the pieces is controlled by card play. All of the pieces may be moved by either player.

"Victory: The first player to score 4 points is the winner. The other player’s team is sacrificed to the gods."

name: Tlatelolco
description:
"Tlatelolco was the great market for the Aztec Empire. The Aztecs had no coins; so all trade was by barter. Players are pochteca (merchants) trying to acquire certain goods."

Players move their pochteca around the 8×8 board to visit merchant stands in the market. Each player is attempt to collect six target goods randomly determined for each player. In addition, the players need to avoid the thief who prowls around the marketplace.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Truckin
description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Players are Truck Drivers. Set in the USA in the 1970’s. Heavy on CB Lingo. Players try to complete routes."

The game uses a custom deck of cards with four suits: Rig, City, Haulin, and Smokey. Each card is marked with a number from 1 to 6, which affect how cards can be combined into melds.

When a meld is played, another player may disrupt it with a Smokey card. If the meld is not disrupted, the player who played it marks off one route as completed.

"Winning: The first player to complete 5 Routes is the winner."

name: Vampire Prince
description:
"2+ Player card game. Players are Elder Vampires vying to be the uncontested Prince of a city. Based on the White Wolf RPG Vampire the Masquerade and the associated Deckmaster card game Jyhad."

The game uses a custom card deck. There are seven different types of cards: Vampire, Event, Location, Political Organization, Combat Event, Modifier, and Damage.

"Victory: Be the first to control cards with a combined political value of 20+ or kill all the opposing Elder Vampires."

name: Mormon Trek
description:
Mormon Trek is a simple roll-and-move designed to promote family discussion about the Mormon Pioneers experiences. Each game piece is a rocking chair that is being carried across the plains in wagon trains. Movement is dictated by die-roll with a custom dice featuring wagons, blessings, and tribulations. A wagon roll simple allows you to move forward. A blessing roll (golden key) lets you move to a special section of the board where you talk about blessings the pioneers experienced. A tribulation roll moves you backwards and requires you to talk about a trial the pioneers experienced.

The first player to successfully travel from Nauvoo, IL to Salt Lake City, UT is the winner.

name: Numbers Game
description: Players have a fixed stack of tiles comprising single digits and simple mathematical operators. In turn, they lay tiles to form an equality, which must (after the first play) link with one already on the board. Fewest tiles remaining at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Game of 45
description:
This game is played on a board with 10 x 10 squares. The goal of the game is to create a line (horizontal, vertical or diagonal) on the board that contains one of each number (the sum of which equals 45, hence the name of the game).

Each player has a rack with ten numbers on it. Each turn, he may take one of two actions:
1) Draw a new tile, and:
a) Place a tile from his rack on the board, and add the newly drawn tile to his rack, or;
b) Place the newly drawn tile on the board;
2) Take a tile from the board and replace it with a tile from his rack.

Whenever a tile is placed on the board, it may not be placed in a row that already contains the same number. The round ends when a player manages to complete one row on the board (or two, in a two player game) while also having completed 'row' on his rack. All players now score points, and a new round starts. The game continues until a agreed-upon number of rounds has been played, or an agreed-upon score is reached.

Home page: http://www.gameof45.com/

name: Lost Continent of Atlantis
description:
Each player controls a party of six adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters searching for the Pearl Trident of Atlantis.

The parties travel deep into the ocean by submarine, after which they don diving suits to explore the submerged Lost Continent. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Undersea Pirates, Giant Squids, mutiny, and running out of air.

The party which returns to the surface with the Pearl Trident wins the game.

A WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

name: Depths of the Earth
description:
Each player controls a party of six adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters journeying into the depths of the Earth in search of Dinosaur Eggs.

The parties traverse tunnels leading into the Earth's crust to reach a lost prehistoric realm hidden deep underground. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Earthquakes, Lava, Mutant Albinos, Simian War Parties, and the dreaded Tyrannosaurus Rex.

The party to return to the surface with the Dinosaur Eggs wins the game.

A WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

name: Voyage of Sinbad
description:
"Each player is an Arabian Swashbuckler Captain in search of Adventure & Fortune."

Each player controls a captain and seven crew members. Hazards that may be faced by the sailors include the Cyclops, Giant Walrus, Serpent Woman, and Sword Fighting Skeletons.

The players are racing to obtain a magic potion that will restore a cursed prince to his human form. The crew to return with the magic potion wins the game.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Adventure, Arabian, Fantasy, Nautical, Print & Play

name: Where Eagles Dared
description:
"Movie 1968…. Commandos, posing as German soldiers, parachute into the Bavarian Alps to rescue a supposed allied general from a Nazi hideaway fortress that can only be reached by cable car. Epic war pic where Richard Burton and Clint Eastwood manage to unmask most of the German spy network in England, slip Jerry the wrong plans for the second front, kill the leading members of the Abwehr in Southern Bavaria, and destroy half of the local Wehrmacht."

Each player controls a Commando Team of seven agents - a major, an American Ranger lieutenant, two commandos, and three traitors. Other team members may be gained during play. The object of the game is to journey through the Alpine wilderness to the Castle of the Eagles, face three challenges, and then escape to a German airfield to be extracted in a disguised aircraft.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Adventure, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents, World War II

name: Beastmaster Quest
description:
Each player is a Beastmaster, as depicted in the movie of the same name.

The object of the game is to be the first player to complete a Beastmaster Quest by reaching the last space on the sixty space game track. Along the way the players will face a variety of challenges, including treachery by the opposing Beastmasters.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Adventure, Fantasy, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Rabbit Run
description:
"Each player controls a Band of Rabbits who have left their overcrowded home Warren and are traveling the countryside, looking for a good spot to establish a new Warren. Based on the Novel Watership Down by Richard Adams."

The winner is the first player to have a band of rabbits reach the end the thirty-space game track.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Animals, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Constantine
description:
"Based on the movie Constantine, which was based on the comic Hellblazer. Each player is a Demon-Hunter/Exorcist."

Each Hunter is rated for the following attributes: Hit Points, Psychic, Contacts, Willpower, Combat, and Morality. The Hunters use these attributes to face Fight, Mental, and Info challenges.

The game is played on a track fifty spaces long. "The last represents the culmination of an infernal plot. The first player to the last space foils the plot and wins the game."

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Fantasy, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Alexander at Arbela
description:
Alexander at Arbela (331 BC)
The map represents the area in which the battle of Gaugamela took place. The battlefield covered a large plain almost entirely flat, except a small area of irregular terrain on the one side of the map, which does not affect the game play.
Each hexagon of the map represents about 200 meters of actual terrain. Since the actual battlefield extended about 6 Km along, the map sheet is consisted of 30 hexagons along and 24 across.
In addition to the map there is included a sheet of paper with the necessary aids to illustrate various aspects of the game. There are the Combat Results Table, the Unit Value Table and Victory Conditions Table.

name: Zoids
description:
